name: Bromomethane
Reason: 1,3-dioxolane has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for our comparison will be methane, which has a melting point of -161.5 degrees Celsius. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of one additional phenyl group. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of Bromomethane, we have one additional phenyl group linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
